ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about collaboration, storytelling through song, the writing process, and ways to make meaningful change through theatre.

Its actually impossible to describe how much I learned in this class, it was so broad and deep and insightful! I think the main things I learned covered storytelling, pacing, and specific musical devices to support plot.

First and foremost I gained such valuable experience listening to classmates' work and discussing how music and storytelling works in a ridiculously talented class. This class was truly a caring, honest, and ambitious community of extremely passionate creative people -- something I've rarely experienced in a Yale classroom setting, even a music one -- and so I always wanted to bring my hardest and most genuine work to class, which really pushed me as a composer and also a human navigating a really difficult semester and time. I feel like I know more about what a musical theater song *does* and was pushed to really think on the macro level as Jeanine urged us to hone in on the story, not the plot, in a pithy "Spielberg pitch" kind of way. I feel not only more capable of idiomatic and catchy musical writing but I think I really came into my own with lyrics for the first time this semester. Unexpectedly (but very gladly, as a music history nerd), I also learned about so many jumping-off points into the world of uncovering marginalized voices in music theater history such as the history of Black musicals in the US. There's so much more I could say. I'm so grateful for this experience.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Prof Tesori, small class size, weekly assignments, feedback, class energy

It was amazing! I dont think the course could be improved in any way. I particularly loved the camaraderie from the small group atmosphere, and the openness of our discussions - nothing was off topic.

It's inherently very hard to compose an original song about once a week, let alone in a full covid-era Yale semester. I think Jeanine balanced high expectations with compassion well and urged us to communicate about our limits and capacities, and that definitely eased the stress of maintaining that kind of output during the semester. I think that the 2-hour seminar format is ideal, and would only wish the class was longer so we could delve more deeply into everyone's work, particularly the technical and musical elements (in addition to the story elements, which we focused on).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! For anyone hoping to pursue a professional career in musical theater, I think this course is the best you can take at Yale to prepare you for that.
Absolutely! I think any student working in musical storytelling would benefit greatly from this course.
This is an absolutely fantastic course. Take it , as long as you're willing to be really challenged and stressed (you're usually writing one song each week!)
